alternative_title: Employers' tax and reporting for meal expenses
overview: Tax and reporting rules for employers providing meals for employees and directors
title: Expenses and benefits: meals for employees and directors

table.body:
As an employer providing meals for your employees, you have certain tax, National Insurance and reporting obligations.

##What’s included

What you have to report and pay depends on:

* the value of the meals
* if they're in a workplace canteen open to all staff
* if they take place on or off your premises
* if they're paid for through employee 'accounts' or vouchers
table.title: Overview

table.body:
You don’t have to report anything to HMRC or pay tax and National Insurance if you offer all your employees:

* free or subsidised meals of a reasonable value at a workplace canteen
* vouchers that cover the cost of buying these meals
* vouchers worth up to 15p per day

%If you offer these meals or vouchers under [salary sacrifice](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/paye/payroll/special-pay/salary-sacrifice.htm "salary sacrifice"){:rel="external"} or [flexible remuneration arrangements](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/manuals/eimanual/eim21676.htm "flexible remuneration arrangements"){:rel="external"} (also known as 'flexible benefit plans'), these won't be exempt.%

##Free or subsidised meals for low-earning employees

You don't have to pay or report on these meals for employees earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of less than £8,500 a year.

*[HMRC]:HM Revenue & Customs
table.title: What's exempt

table.body:
If the meals or vouchers you provide aren't [exempt](/expenses-and-benefits-meals-for-employees-and-directors/whats-exempt "exempt"), you may have to report them to HMRC. You may have to deduct and pay tax and National Insurance on the costs.

##Free or subsidised meals that aren't exempt

This includes meals that:

* aren't on a reasonable scale, eg elaborate meals with fine wines
* are provided off-site but not at a canteen, eg at a restaurant
* aren't available to all staff, eg meals for directors only
* provided under [salary sacrifice](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/paye/payroll/special-pay/salary-sacrifice.htm "salary sacrifice"){:rel="external"} or [flexible remuneration arrangements](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/manuals/eimanual/eim21676.htm "flexible remuneration arrangements"){:rel="external"} (also known as 'flexible benefit plans')

If you provide these meals to employees earning at a rate of £8,500 a year or more, or directors, you'll need to:

* report on form P11D, section M
* pay Class 1A National Insurance on the cost to you

##Vouchers for meals outside the workplace

You need to report and pay on the cost of vouchers above 15p per day.

Who gets the benefit | What to do | What to deduct or pay
- | - | -
Employees earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of less than £8,500 a year | Report on form P9D, section B | Class 1 National Insurance on the cost above 15p per day through payroll
Employees earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of £8,500 or more a year | Report on form P11D, section C | Class 1 National Insurance on the cost above 15p per day through payroll
Directors | Report on form P11D, section C | Class 1 National Insurance on the cost above 15p per day through payroll

##Other vouchers, cash allowances or employee accounts

If you provide any of the following, this counts as earnings:

* vouchers that can be exchanged for either food or cash
* cash allowances for meals
* top-up payments to an employee's account for workplace food and drink using a card or PIN system

For these costs, you'll need to:

* add the amount to the employee's other earnings
* deduct and pay PAYE tax and Class 1 National Insurance through payroll

*[HMRC]:HM Revenue & Customs
*[PAYE]:Pay As You Earn
